dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The FBI is actually commending Tesla, not investigating them—that's huge.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The companys better-than-expected quarterly profit was driven by that car, but it took half a year longer than CEO Elon Musk had predicted to reach a production pace of 5,000 Model 3s per week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they started production in Fremont back in 2016, much earlier than people expected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they started production in Fremont back in twenty sixteen, much earlier than people expected.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Musk had said early last year that production of Model 3, currently priced from $46,000, would reach 5,000 units per week in 2017s fourth quarter, and reiterated that target in July 2017 after production of it began in Fremont, California.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB

dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Musk even got praised by the S E C for his, uh, business insight.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The SEC had sued the billionaire for comments the regulator viewed as share price manipulation. As part of a settlement concluded this month, Musk agreed to step down as Teslas chairman, a position he assumed long before becoming its CEO, and pay a $20 million fine to settle the matter.

dialogue_turns.text: Which is ironic given all the past controversies, but hey, results speak.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is ironic given all the past controversies, but hey, results speak.

dialogue_turns.text: Their strategy of setting low targets to guarantee success clearly paid off.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Their strategy of setting low targets to guarantee success clearly paid off.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tesla defended its past statements, and that its philosophy has always been to set truthful targets not sandbagged targets that we would definitely exceed and not unrealistic targets that we could never meet.

artist_script:
Tesla's Model 3 production is a textbook case of corporate transparency and execution.
HostA: The FBI is actually commending Tesla, not investigating them—that’s huge.
HostB: Yeah, and they hit that 10,000 Model 3s per week mark way ahead of schedule.
HostA: Right? Elon Musk’s initial predictions were ambitious, but they actually exceeded them.
HostB: And the Wall Street Journal report was completely fabricated, which is wild.
HostA: It’s interesting though, because Tesla’s stock still dropped by 5% today.
HostB: Yeah, but that might just be market noise—their quarterly profits are stellar thanks to the Model 3.
HostA: And they started production in Fremont back in 2016, much earlier than people expected.
HostB: They built nearly 30,000 cars that year alone—that’s impressive for a new model launch.
HostA: And Musk even got praised by the SEC for his, uh, business insight.
HostB: Which is ironic given all the past controversies, but hey, results speak.
HostA: Their strategy of setting low targets to guarantee success clearly paid off.
HostB: I mean, finishing three months early on their 10k-per-week goal? That’s execution.
HostA: And now Musk is taking a more active role as chairman again.
HostB: With a bonus to match—definitely a good month for Tesla.
